The Hawaii State Senate unanimously approved Senate Bill 2046 Wednesday, which would prohibit the manufacture, sale, transfer, and possession of bump stocks and similar devices. The bump stock, which allows semi-automatic firearms to fire similarly to automatic weapons, was linked with the October 2017 mass shooting in Las Vegas. The Hawaii Rifle Association, a National Rifle Association affiliate, opposed the bill. President Harvey Gerwig wrote in testimony that the bill was vague, overreaching, and would "turn an innocent gun owner into a felon." According to the Honolulu Civil Beat, the bill did not receive much other opposition.
Reevaluated the odds: it will happen but not in the time frame prescribed.

http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/714184 I think it's just barely possible this will be completed within the given time frame.  Unless there is pressure to immediately post the new rule after the 90-day submission (Mar 23- June 21), I would imagine the review of public comments would take more than a couple of days (or at least it did for the FCC vote last year and it was clear from the outset that both Trump and Pai were pushing as hard as they could, though the FCC is an independent regulatory agency and I'm not sure if the ATF is).  They seem to have a somewhat different rule-making procedure, but their process is probably more pro forma at this point than desperate to change a policy as quickly as possible or to make a big public announcement for significant political points.  Sessions chose a 90-day comment period instead of 60, though the reg-map suggests that "Executive Order 12866 established 60 days as the standard for the comment period."  On the other hand, they pushed the review through OMB in less than 30 days, which seems a little impressive to me since I think the law gives OMB/OIRA 90 days to review rules. After the 90-day comment period, no matter how long it takes to create a final rule (and I'm guessing they won't change the arguments internally much since 1) they already countered their own argument that bump stocks didn't meet the "multiple trigger pull" definition they made 3 months ago and 2) since they've estimated this will costs millions and put 1 of 2 companies making bump stocks out of business and have significant economic impact and yet are still arguing that 3) the rule is required to take care of the "negative externality" that bump stocks are being used for crime regardless of their reason for purchase and that the economic mechanisms can't manage the criminal results that nevertheless ensue (p26 https://www.justice.gov/file/1046006/download).  If they've already countered the 5 or 6 most likely bitter and deep (and reasonable) complaints about making bump stocks illegal (and they seem fairly comprehensive to me), then there's not much they seem likely to substantially change.   Still, once a final rule is made, it has to be published in the Register and for any kind of significant rule (which affect small businesses or has a "significant economic impact" - not sure how OMB ruled on how significant millions of dollars is for a few thousand businesses, 400,000 owners and 550,000 pieces of equipment down the drain) for public notice for an additional 30 or even 60 days before before it goes into effect.  If the law counts as the "ban" to meet the question requirements, then July 1 might just barely be enough time.  But it seems likely to take more than 7 business days even to get to the public register publication of a final rule.  Maybe I just overestimate the pace at which government offices and oversight work.

https://www.regulations.gov/searchResults?rpp=25&so=DESC&sb=postedDate&po=0&dct=PR%2BFR%2BN&np=7&cp=O%2BC I think what has happened so far is just an announcement.   As I recall (always a tenuous starting point, especially since I haven't had to mux about in this stuff for several decades), they have to publish the full proposed rule in the Federal Register, and that's what starts the 90-day comment period.  After that, they have to publish the final rule in the Register, but they don't have to do that right away--and if they want to make significant changes, they file an amended proposed rule and start over again, I think.  (There is an earlier step, the notice of a proposed rule, which happened in December but as I recall doesn't affect any deadlines other than the comment deadline on the Notice.) Far as I can tell, the proposed rule hasn't hit the Register yet, so the 90-day countdown can't start until Monday at the earliest; that's the 26th.   They could just barely hit the 1 July deadline if they publish on the 26th: The 91st day is I think Sunday, 24 June, but the Register doesn't come out on weekends, so the very earliest possible date to effectively promulgate the reg would be Monday, 25 June--and that's if they do all the bits as soon as possible and don't decide to file an amended proposed reg.  It is not hard to imagine that feet will be dragged. So I'm coming up a bit but not much.  I still harbor a suspicion that they will figure out a way to render this proposal meaningless, or amend it to death, or quietly withdraw it, or in some other wise cause it to disappear. One supposes the NRA will file a suit immediately, but I'm pretty sure no court would grant an injunction to suspend or prevent the rulemaking process--since the rule won't have been promulgated yet, there can't be any harm for an injunction to prevent.  And I suppose this Q would still be a Yes even if they get an injunction the next morning.   I am fully prepared, and indeed would be delighted, to be corrected about any or all of this.  It's been a long time since I had much practice in the wonderful world of federal rulemaking.

Trump wants to ban bump stocks; ATF doesn't know if it can Gurman (2018) February 22, states that: President Donald Trump has ordered his Justice Department to work toward banning rapid-fire bump stocks like the ones used in last year's Las Vegas massacre— but officials aren't sure they can. Trump's surprise orders this week comes as officials from the department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives are well into a review of whether they can regulate the devices without action from Congress. The path to a ban is neither simple nor quick. An ATF ban on the accessories, which allow semi-automatic rifles to mimic machine guns, would likely thrust the department into a prolonged legal battle with gun manufacturers while the devices remain on the market. But any congressional effort to create new gun control laws would need support from the pro-gun Republican majority. And Republicans have moved in the other direction, attempting to loosen gun laws, even after 59 people were killed in Las Vegas. Despite the president stepping up pressure on the department in the aftermath of the Florida high school shooting, some ATF officials maintain that only Congress can render such devices illegal, and, in any event, amending existing gun laws or passing new legislation would be a faster approach. Acting ATF director Thomas Brandon has sent mixed signals on what the agency can do. He told lawmakers in December that the ATF and Justice Department would not have initiated the review if a ban "wasn't a possibility at the end," but he has also expressed doubt that it would be able to do so without congressional intervention (para. 1-5).
